text:
hi all here are some frequent discussed questions:
1. Wechat payment, I want to correct that to set up WeChat transfer you need a Chinese mobile number and a Chinese bank account. Although one can link a foreign credit card to WeChat, it is limited only to certain payments. So for travelers, it is not easy to have WeChat payment (I am sorry for that!). So always bring some cash with you!
2. Simcards can be purchased easily in mobile service providers, but you need to show your visa, passport, and it isn't expensive. the most used provider is China mobile (best network), but there are also China Unicom, china telecom.
Best regards, 
Yan :face-red-heart-shape:

text:
Just get back from my first visit in China (09.2023):

* Even in big cities, people barely speak English, especially it's frustrating in places where tourists cross often (train stations, tourist attractions, etc). 
  And well, they are not always so helpful, I often was left with no help, as they cannot understand my Chinese (and they cannot speak English). 
  Translate application don't help much.


* Express VPN not working in China (drops connection, unstable)
* Payments and linking card in Wechat is finally possible for foreigner (European cards) - Wechat - Alipay, but sometimes I was unable to pay for very tiny shops.
* Payments by cash are possible, sometimes I was forced to use it as, allipay/wechat not work :( 

* Google Map is almost useless, and getting around with Chineese map, not knowing how to read Chinese, well ... 
* Ctrip / Hotels, Often the hotels put they support foreigner visitors but in fact, after arriving they say they cannot (haha). 
   This is happen to me a lot as I was trying to book cheap ones. No problem with expensive ones, seems like they have qualification.
   Even I don't sleep to much in hotels, it drives me crazy to run between hotels and finally finding the one to stay... 
  ( I used the option mentioned in video, quarel in the middle of the night with Hotels owners, but let's leave that stories behind) 

* Trains, buying train tickets on the go/fly it's often impossible - I mean (sit tickets / sleep tickets). 
   On popular directions you should buy at least one day before to get a seat place. 
   I often ride without seats, because I never plan my trip ahead of time. Just decide on the go.

* At XinJiang province - filming police-man / police-car is forbidden, and if not respected you can go to jail for 5 days (well don't ask how I know it) 
* Language barrier is huge, especially outside of big cities. Ask for help in China-Xinjiang in English and well you won't receive any no help :)

* My personal opinion: Native Chinese people (not speaking about Uyghur from Xinjiang), are much less hospitable than those from: Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan. 
  Are rarely get any free food invitation, I was never invited to stay in home. I have often ask for help and get little or no help when really needed.

* If you want to go to some park, temples, other cool attractions. You need to reserve tickets through some wechat full in Chinese application. Sometimes tickets are on the place, but often there are no tickets for the given day.

* Simcard need to be registered via passport it took the guy around 30minutes to go through it,  cost me around 100 yuan. Good to know that are separate packages for the single province and global china. (Internal/Domestic)

---------

Future traveler: 
If you believe that you can travel through China like in Europe, no you can't.
Although I enjoy my stay in China, Hitchike Traveling itself was so far the hardest experience I got.

text:
Except this, travelling in Xinjiang (lots of controls on the road), Gansu, Qinghai, Ningxia, and Shaanxi, along the Silk Road has been quite easy thank to:
- Google Translate (I don't speak Mandarin, neither read sinograms),
- Maps.me (or equivalent) with pre recorded destinations on pre downloaded maps,
- intensive transportation planning (including local buses),
- efficient railways and long distance busses (despite very long delay for trains in Xinjiang),
- well organized touristical places,
- helping and welcoming people along the road.
I paid everything cash. Most of train tickets booked online, some face-to-face, where you'd better to know possibilities in advance and prepare your demands on Google Translate using the writing mode (can be used offline üòâ). Knowing how to count in Mandarin (and with a single hand) helps. Courtesy words are of course opening formulas as in any country.

text: I can testify that. Took my better half and his family (foreigner) visit and travel in Xinjiang for one month, and we were booked all the way in those authorized hotels. Some places we unfortunetly couldnt stay overnight to visit just because no hotels nearby are authorized. But we were albe to visit all cities in Xinjiang except for the bordering area where foreigners need special permit. In some cities though, check points are much more frequently, like in Kuche every 1 km there was a check point (checking identity documents). As I told my family in law that XJ at that time was such senstive place since the riot, they were mentally prepared but I guess for many foreigners that would not be a very pleasant experience. However we visited it in 2017, after that we all know Xinjiang area become the hot topic in global media and I guess situation would be worse.

text:
hi all here are some frequent discussed questions:
1. Wechat payment, I want to correct that to set up WeChat transfer you need a Chinese mobile number and a Chinese bank account. Although one can link a foreign credit card to WeChat, it is limited only to certain payments. So for travelers, it is not easy to have WeChat payment (I am sorry for that!). So always bring some cash with you!
2. Simcards can be purchased easily in mobile service providers, but you need to show your visa, passport, and it isn't expensive. the most used provider is China mobile (best network), but there are also China Unicom, china telecom.
Best regards, 
Yan :face-red-heart-shape:

text: As a Chinese whose mobile phone number in China had been deactivated for a long time, I can empathize with the difficulties faced by those who do not possess a valid Chinese mobile phone number. It is mandatory to have a local phone number to register for many apps, including WeChat and Alipay. Although it is easy for a Chinese to obtain a SIM card with a local phone number from any local service hall in China, it is unclear whether foreigners can purchase a SIM card using their travel pass as identification. It is recommended to check with local mobile service providers' websites, such as China Mobile, before arriving in mainland China.

author: @fekkyb

text:
I've been to China 5 times for work for months at a time, but half the time was leisure lol. 

I have little to no Mandarin skills, I basically got along with Google translate, hand gestures and showing people my phone. 

As for apps, WeChat (it's very hard to get WeChat pay with foreign acct) and Alipay feature, any VPN. Cash is not used very often, so definitely try Alipay. Didi is quite helpful as well, it's like Uber.

Public transportation is amongst the best I've seen ever. Most signs have English translation on it. I took the bullet train from Guangzhou to Beijing (also to Hong Kong and  Shenzhen) and took the subway within the city. Extremely clean, efficient and cheap. You can pretty much get anywhere with public transportation.

Just don't be afraid to ask, people will really try to help you most of the time.
